options.C: Weld expansion joints solid for strength
options.D: Expansion joint fit-up doesn't require special attention

explanations.A: Expansion joints have specific fit-up requirements: maintaining clearances, ensuring alignment, preventing restriction. They're designed to allow movement, not be rigidly welded.
explanations.B: Expansion joint fit-up: maintain specified clearances for designed thermal expansion range, align components for free sliding motion without binding, verify welds don't restrict movement (weld only specified locations), position at mid-travel point if specified allowing equal expansion/contraction, apply appropriate lubricant to sliding surfaces if required, protect sliding surfaces and clearances from weld spatter causing binding. Proper fit-up ensures expansion joint functions as designed.
explanations.C: Welding expansion joints solid defeats their purpose and creates: thermal stress, potential cracking, piping system failure, pipe buckling. Only specified attachment welds should be made allowing designed movement.
explanations.D: Expansion joints require careful fit-up ensuring: clearances maintained, alignment for free movement, protection during welding, proper positioning. Critical that joints can function as designed.

questions.question: What is the purpose of final dimensional verification before releasing assembly from fabrication?

options.A: Final verification is unnecessary if in-process checks were performed
options.B: Final verification: confirms all dimensions meet specifications after all operations, verifies welding distortion within acceptable limits, provides as-built dimensions for records, ensures assembly meets interface requirements, satisfies quality acceptance criteria
options.C: Visual inspection replaces dimensional verification
options.D: Fabrication dimensional control ends after assembly

explanations.A: Final verification is essential because: dimensions can change during final operations, cumulative effects become apparent only at completion, provides acceptance documentation, confirms assembly ready for next phase. In-process checks don't eliminate need for final verification.
explanations.B: Final verification purposes: confirms all critical dimensions within specified tolerances after all fabrication complete, verifies distortion from welding and other processes within acceptable limits, documents as-built dimensions for permanent records (especially for deviations from nominal), ensures assembly meets interface requirements for mating with other components, satisfies quality acceptance criteria for release from fabrication. Final check is formal acceptance verification.
explanations.C: Visual inspection doesn't verify dimensions to required precision. Measurement with calibrated tools is required for dimensional acceptance. Visual inspection supplements but doesn't replace measurement.
explanations.D: Dimensional control continues through: final verification, acceptance testing, final inspection. Fabrication dimensional verification is formal gate before assembly release for shipment or installation.

questions.question: What preparation is required for welding materials that will be subjected to low-temperature service?

options.A: Low-temperature service requires no special preparation
options.B: Preparation considerations: verify material is specified for low-temperature service (impact tested), ensure proper filler metal selection, extra care removing notches and stress concentrations, thorough weld quality control, complete joint preparation preventing defects
options.C: All materials perform equally at low temperature
options.D: Low-temperature materials are prepared identically to ambient service

explanations.A: Low-temperature service creates unique challenges: brittle fracture risk, material selection critical, defect tolerance reduced. Special attention throughout preparation and welding is essential.
explanations.B: Low-temperature preparation: verify base metal has required low-temperature toughness (Charpy impact tested), confirm filler metal specified for low-temperature service, extra care removing notches and stress concentrations (brittle fracture initiation sites), thorough preparation ensuring complete fusion and penetration (defects more critical in low-temperature), possibly tighter tolerance on fit-up, enhanced quality control. Low-temperature service is less forgiving of defects and stress concentrations requiring more rigorous preparation and welding.
explanations.C: Many materials become brittle at low temperature losing toughness and ductility. Material selection and verification critical for low-temperature applications. Only specified materials are acceptable.
explanations.D: Low-temperature service requires: verified material toughness, proper filler metals, enhanced quality control, extra care avoiding defects. More rigorous attention required than ambient service.

questions.question: How should field fit-up tolerances be managed when shop fabrication precision is not achievable?

options.A: Field work requires no tolerance management
options.B: Field tolerance management: provide adjustment capability in design (slotted holes, shims, adjustable connections), measure actual conditions before final fit-up, use templates or jigs when practical, sequential fit checking catching problems early, realistic tolerances accounting for field conditions
options.C: Field work can ignore all tolerances
options.D: Force components to fit regardless of tolerance deviation

explanations.A: Field work requires careful tolerance management due to: less precise conditions, accumulated tolerances from multiple shop assemblies, environmental factors. Management prevents fit-up failures in field.
explanations.B: Field tolerance strategies: design includes adjustment provisions (slotted bolt holes, shim spaces, adjustable connections), measure actual as-built conditions before attempting fit-up, use templates or temporary jigs verifying fit before final assembly, progressive fit checking catching problems early when correction is easier, specify realistic tolerances acknowledging field limitations. Field tolerances are typically wider than shop but still require management preventing fit-up failure.
explanations.C: Field assemblies must still meet functional requirements and code specifications. While tolerances may be relaxed from shop work, tolerance specifications still exist ensuring assemblies function properly.
explanations.D: Forcing creates same problems in field as shop: high stress, potential damage, unsafe conditions. Field fit problems should be resolved through: proper measurement, engineering consultation, approved corrections, not forcing.

questions.question: What final checks should be performed on completed assemblies before they leave fabrication control?

options.A: No final checks needed once welding is complete
options.B: Final checks include: dimensional verification against specifications, visual weld inspection, required NDE complete and acceptable, surface finish and cleanliness, protection for shipping, identification marking, documentation package complete, customer acceptance if required
options.C: Visual appearance is the only final check
options.D: Individual welder approval is sufficient for release

explanations.A: Final checks are formal acceptance verification ensuring: all specifications met, quality verified, documentation complete, assembly ready for shipment or installation. Critical quality gate before release.
explanations.B: Final assembly checks: dimensional verification confirming all critical dimensions within tolerance, visual weld inspection for surface defects, required non-destructive examination (RT, UT, MT, PT) complete with acceptable results, surface finish and cleanliness meeting specifications, proper protection for shipping (preservative, packaging), permanent identification marking (heat numbers, part numbers, fabricator), documentation package complete (material certs, procedure records, NDE reports, as-built drawings), customer witness or acceptance if specified. Comprehensive verification ensures assembly meets all requirements before leaving fabrication control.
explanations.C: Visual inspection is one element but doesn't verify: dimensions, internal weld quality, material properties, documentation completeness. Comprehensive checks across all requirements are necessary.
explanations.D: Individual welder completes their work but formal release requires: quality inspection, dimensional verification, documentation review, management approval. Multiple levels of verification ensure assembly meets all requirements.
